You have them voting to pass Republican legislation. You have the Senate Minority leader going on a book tour. Comment: An outsider's perspective, from years of looking at US politics in bewilderment from a more traditional "Westminster" style democracy (Australia). Here, we are used to a fairly organised party structure with s defined party platform decided by party members, a leadership team chosen under the rules of whichever party it is, and pretty strictly enforced party rules. There's a leader, a deputy, a cabinet or shadow cabinet of ministers responsible for portfolios, and the leaders are members of parliament, and directly accountable via parliament to the people. The idea of an opposition party or parties without a clearly identified leader is quite unfamiliar to us.  The very first thing a party that's lost an election here (as happened this week in Australia) is to sort out its leadership and start working on its policy platform for the years ahead. Utterly bizarre to us as outsiders watching the Democrats infighting and rudderless and disunited this far into the Trump second term.
Author: Hairy_rambutan
